cleaned_text: Scientific advice and protocol assistance Table of contents [From lab to patient: journey of a medicine](#from-lab-to-patient:-journey-of-a-medicine-section) [How scientific advice works](#how-scientific-advice-works-section) [When scientific advice most useful](#when-is-scientific-advice-most-useful-section) [Types of questions outside the [Protocol assistance](#protocol-assistance-section) [Steps of the process](#steps-of-the-process-section) [Why following scientific advice does not guarantee marketing authorisation](#why-following-scientific-advice-does-not-guarantee-marketing-authorisation-section) [What EMA publishes on outcomes of scientific advice](#what-ema-publishes-on-outcomes-of-scientific-advice-section) [Parallel scientific advice with the United States](#parallel-scientific-advice-with-the-united-states-section) [Scientific advice on medicine repurposing](#scientific-advice-on-medicine-repurposing-section) [Scientific advice on post-authorisation safety studies (PASS)](#scientific-advice-on-post-authorisation-safety-studies-(pass)-section) [Parallel consultations regulators and HTA bodies](#parallel-consultations-from-regulators-and-hta-bodies-section) [Scientific advice on biosimilars](#scientific-advice-on-biosimilars-section) [Medicines intended for a disease causing public health emergency](#medicines-intended-for-a-disease-causing-public-health-emergency-section) The European Medicines Agency (EMA) can provide medicine developers advice on the most appropriate way to generate robust evidence on a medicine's benefits and risks. EMA provides [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) to support the timely and sound development of high-quality, effective and safe medicines, for the benefit of patients. At any stage of a medicine's development, a developer can ask guidance and direction from EMA on the best methods and study designs to generate robust information on how well a medicine works and how safe it is, regardless of whether the medicine is eligible for the [centralised authorisation procedure](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/about-us/what-we-do/authorisation-medicines) or not. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) helps to ensure that developers perform the appropriate tests and studies, so that no major objections regarding the design of the tests are likely to be raised during the evaluation of the marketing authorisation application. This also helps avoid patients taking part in studies that will not produce useful evidence. For human medicines, [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) and [protocol assistance](/en/glossary/protocol-assistance) are given by the [Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use](/en/glossary/committee-medicinal-products-human-use) ( [CHMP](/en/glossary/chmp)) on the recommendation of the [Scientific Advice Working Party](/en/committes/working-parties-other-groups/chmp/scientific-advice-working-party) (SAWP). However, in the case of medicines that are intended to treat, prevent or diagnose a disease causing a declared public health emergency, [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) is given by the [CHMP](/en/glossary/chmp) based on recommendation of the Emergency Task Force (ETF). [Prospective applicants who are completely new to ](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/from-lab-to-patient-timeline) [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice)or have little prior interaction with medicines regulators may benefit from reviewing the journey of a medicine for human use assessed by EMA in this interactive timeline, as a first step. This timeline explains all stages - from initial research to patient access - including how EMA supports medicine development, assesses the benefits and risks and monitors the safety of medicines. The full text is available as a [booklet](https://www.ema.europa.eu/documents/other/laboratory-patient-journey-centrally-authorised-medicine_en.pdf) . For information on how to request [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) from EMA, see [Requesting scientific advice or protocol assistance from EMA](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/research-development/scientific-advice-protocol-assistance/requesting-scientific-advice-protocol-assistance-ema). EMA gives [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) by responding to specific questions posed by the medicine developer on the development of a particular medicine. The developer of a medicine presents the way it plans to develop its medicine and identifies questions and possible solutions. EMA then gives advice on the developer's proposals. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) is prospective in nature. EMA does not pre-evaluate the results of the studies and in no way concludes on whether the benefits of the medicine outweigh the risks. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) from EMA is not legally binding on EMA or on the medicine developer with regard to any future [marketing authorisation applications](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation-application) for the medicine concerned. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) and [protocol assistance](/en/glossary/protocol-assistance) are particularly useful to medicine developers when: - they are developing an [innovative medicine](/en/glossary/innovative-medicine)and there appears to be no or insufficient relevant detail in EU [guidelines](/en/glossary/guideline)or guidance documents, or in Pharmacopoeia monographs, including draft documents or monographs released for consultation; - they are developing new or repurposed medicines targeting (re)emerging pathogens for which there is an unmet medical need but insufficient or no guidance is available; - the developer chooses to deviate from scientific [guidelines](/en/glossary/guideline)in its development plan; - the medicine developer has limited knowledge about medicine regulation, such as some [academic groups](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/partners-networks/academia)or [micro, small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs)](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/overview/support-smes). Medicine developers can request [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) or [protocol assistance](/en/glossary/protocol-assistance) either during the initial development of a medicine before submission of a [marketing authorisation application](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation-application) or later on, during the post-authorisation phase. Questions during [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) can relate to: - quality aspects (e.g. manufacturing, chemical, pharmaceutical and biological testing of the medicine); - non-clinical aspects (e.g. toxicological and pharmacological tests designed to show the activity of the medicine in the laboratory); - clinical aspects (e.g. appropriateness of studies in patients or healthy volunteers, selection of endpoints, i.e. how best to measure effects in a study, post-authorisation activities including [risk management plans](/en/glossary/risk-management-plan)); - methodological issues (e.g. statistical tests to use, data analysis, [modelling and simulation](/en/glossary/modelling-simulation)); - overall development strategy (e.g., [conditional marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/conditional-marketing-authorisation), bridging strategy for generics, safety database), significant benefit for maintaining [orphan designation](/en/glossary/orphan-designation), and paediatric developments. Examples of questions Questions about the topics below are outside the scope of [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice): assessment](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/marketing-authorisation/accelerated-assessment) - Adequacy of planned paediatric studies or an overall development plan to support a paediatric [indication](/en/glossary/indication), which EMA addresses via a PIP submission - Changes to the key elements of [Paediatric Investigation Plan](/en/glossary/paediatric-investigation-plan)(PIP) measures and [paediatric waivers or deferrals](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/research-development/paediatric-medicines/paediatric-investigation-plans#deferrals-and-waivers-section), which EMA addresses via a [paediatric procedure](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/overview/paediatric-medicines-overview) - Matters of a purely regulatory nature (please use the 'Submission Details' field in your submission via the [IRIS portal](https://iris.ema.europa.eu/)) - Adequacy of existing data for assessment of a regulatory application (e.g. a [clinical trial application](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/human-regulatory/research-development/clinical-trials-human-medicines)or [marketing authorisation application](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation-application)). However, please include existing data expected to inform the discussion of questions on further development steps in the [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice)briefing documentation Examples of questions [Protocol assistance](/en/glossary/protocol-assistance) is the special form of [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) available for developers of [designated orphan medicines](/en/human-regulatory/overview/orphan-designation) for rare diseases. In addition to [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice), developers of [orphan medicines](/en/glossary/orphan-medicine) can receive answers to questions relating to the criteria for authorisation of an [orphan medicine](/en/glossary/orphan-medicine). These include: - the demonstration of significant benefit within the scope of the designated orphan [indication](/en/glossary/indication); - similarity or clinical superiority over other medicines. This is relevant if other orphan [medicinal products](/en/glossary/medicinal-product)exist that might be similar to the product concerned and which have [market exclusivity](/en/glossary/market-exclusivity)in the same [indication](/en/glossary/indication). 1. Each team prepares a report addressing the scientific questions; they draft a list of issues for discussion with all the other members of the SAWP and may ask the applicant for any additional documents or clarifications. 5. Meeting with developer (if requested by SAWP) If the SAWP wishes to discuss specific issues with the medicine developer it will organise a meeting, particularly where it disagrees with the proposed plan and proposes alternative development plans. 6. Consulting experts The SAWP consults relevant EMA committees (for example EMA's Additional external experts may also be consulted, further widening the pool of expertise the SAWP can call on. 7. Consulting patients Patients are also often consulted. If EMA decides to respond to the medicine developer in writing, patients are asked to provide comments; if EMA decides to meet with the medicine developer, patients are invited to attend. 7. EMA final response The SAWP consolidates a response to the scientific questions. Final advice is discussed and adopted by the [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) and the assessment of the benefits and risks of a medicine are different by nature. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) looks at how a medicine should be tested in studies to generate robust evidence, while the assessment at the time of [marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation) looks at the evidence generated to determine whether the medicine's benefits outweigh its risks, regardless of any advice previously given. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) can make the evaluation of a medicine easier and quicker because the evidence is likely to be more robust, appropriate and complete, but it does not affect the stringent assessment of safety and [efficacy](/en/glossary/efficacy). Complying with [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) therefore increases the chances of receiving [marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation) but it does not guarantee it. During the development and assessment phases, the detailed advice given to a medicine developer is not made public. This is because disclosing information at this stage may undermine research and development efforts and discourage research in new medicines. However, information is made available after a medicine obtains [marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation). All medicines whose assessment report was finalised after 1 January 2019 include a summary of the developer's questions and key elements of EMA's advice and whether or not the developer complied with this advice within the assessment report. During a declared public health emergency, EMA publishes a list of medicines that have received informal or formal advice from the [CHMP](/en/glossary/chmp) and the ETF. In addition, the full advice can be made available upon request. For more information, see [Access to documents](https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/about-us/how-we-work/access-documents). [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) is also one of the main sources for updating EMA scientific [guidelines](/en/glossary/guideline) on medicine development, including, in particular, disease-specific [guidelines](/en/glossary/guideline). - List item Question and Answers on repurposing pilot project on proposal for framework to support not-for-profit organisations and academia in repurposing published: 28/10/2021 Last updated: 04/02/2022 - List item Submission form - Repurposing pilot project for authorised medicines (DOCX/137.24 KB) First [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) [protocol assistance](/en/glossary/protocol-assistance) in parallel with the United States [Food and Drug Administration](http://www.fda.gov/) (FDA). - List item General principles: European Medicines Agency-Food and Drug Administration parallel scientific advice (PDF/150.31 KB) First published: 22/07/2009 Last updated: 18/08/2021 - List item Timeline: European Agency-FDA parallel advice (PDF/107.64 KB) First published: 19/05/2017 Last updated: 02/02/2023 EMA and FDA launched a pilot programme in September 2021 to provide parallel [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) to [marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation) applicants for hybrid or complex generic products. More information is available in the documents below: Through a pilot project, EMA and [national competent authorities](/en/glossary/national-competent-authority) can offer tailored [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) to not-for-profit organisations and academics (institutions and individuals) on repurposing an authorised medicine for a new [indication](/en/glossary/indication). The aim is to help gather or generate enough evidence to support a new [indication](/en/glossary/indication) with important public health benefits for a medicine whose [marketing authorisation holder](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation-holder) is otherwise unlikely to undertake the necessary research and regulatory steps. This provides a way of making new treatment options available to patients if it leads to the authorisation of the new [indication](/en/glossary/indication). [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) fees are waived automatically for eligible academic sponsors repurposing a medicine for an orphan condition. Fees will also be waived for a subset of other applicants based on the expected public health benefits and strength of the evidence in their application. The deadline to apply was 28 February 2022 More information including eligibility criteria is available in the documents below. EMA encourages medicine developers to seek [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) for PASS protocols. This voluntary, optional procedure will help to improve the design of studies meant to collect further information on a medicine's safety once it is on the market. EMA ran a 12-month pilot for this procedure between July 2015-2016. For more information, see: - Question on ' [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice)for safety studies' on our page [Post-authorisation safety studies: questions and answers](/en/human-regulatory/post-authorisation/pharmacovigilance/post-authorisation-safety-studies-pass). The European Medicines Agency (EMA) offers consultations in parallel with the European Network for Health Technology Assessment (EUnetHTA) 21 consortium. This aims to allow medicine developers to obtain feedback from regulators and [health technology assessment (HTA) bodies](/en/glossary/health-technology-assessment-body) in European Union (EU) Member States on their evidence-generation plans to support decision-making on [marketing authorisation](/en/glossary/marketing-authorisation) and reimbursement of new medicines at the same time. For more information, see [Parallel consultation with regulators and health technology assessment bodies](/en/human-regulatory/research-development/scientific-advice-protocol-assistance/parallel-consultation-regulators-health-technology-assessment-bodies). EMA offers tailored [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) on development programmes of new biosimiliar medicines. The tailored procedure advises developers on the studies they should conduct, based on a review of the quality, analytical and functional data they already have available. The tailored [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) procedure is open to all types of biosimilars and companies are encouraged to request a pre-submission meeting to review the suitability of the data package. Applicants should note that the SAWP will need an extra month in addition to normal [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) timelines to review applications. EMA first introduced the tailored procedure as a pilot project in 2017. A report on the pilot phase is available below. - List item Tailored Scientific advice to support step-by-step development of new biosimilars (PDF/103.56 KB) First published: 16/12/2016 Last updated: 14/10/2021 List item Tailored Scientific Advice for biosimilar development: report on the experience from the pilot (2017-2020) (PDF/168.38 KB) First published: 14/10/2021 EMA/297462/2021 EMA has a dedicated [Emergency Task Force (ETF)](http://www.ema.europa.eu/en/committees/working-parties-other-groups/emergency-task-force-etf) to support its [Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use](/en/glossary/committee-medicinal-products-human-use) ( [CHMP](/en/glossary/chmp)) in providing [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) for new or repurposed human medicines that are intended to treat, prevent or diagnose a disease causing a declared public health emergency. On a case-by-case basis, the ETF also provides advice on medicines targeting selected pathogens that can potentially cause a public health emergency. EMA encourages developers of such medicines to contact the Agency early if they are interested in the following procedures: - Early guidance on medicine development plan (when the plan is not yet suitable for formal [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice)) - Requesting [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) - Applying for a marketing authorisation They can contact EMA by writing to [PHEearlyinteractions@ema.europa.eu](mailto:pheearlyinteractions@ema.europa.eu). Early contact is particularly important during a declared public health emergency. When submitting a request for [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice), developers should indicate in their application form in which Member State(s) they intend to run [clinical trials](/en/glossary/clinical-trial). The ETF requires this information because it involves [clinical trial](/en/glossary/clinical-trial) experts from these Member State(s) in preparing the [scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice), in order to facilitate approval of the trial later in the process. [Scientific advice](/en/glossary/scientific-advice) on the clinical aspects of medicine development or on [clinical trials](/en/glossary/clinical-trial) protocols is free of charge for medicines intended for a disease causing public health emergency.
